description.text:
Please read the following notes.

InputA&B (Enclosure guide):

This is a 2pc snap in unit. This encapsulates 5 magnetic 3mm ball bearings. place both on the same build to help cool down during build. For best result use 0.15mm layer and slower speed, this has a single wall snap in feature.

Bottom Section & Top Cover (Extruder guide):
This is a 2 pcs snap in design. This again uses 5 magnetic 3mm ball bearings. I suggest using support to build both, but make sure on the bottom section part, you remove the support inside the key hole for the top cover. If not you wont be able to insert the top cover.
I also included a small 10x1mm indent on the longer leg, this was designed so you can install a round cabinet bumper or pad. Adding one will increase the grip on the extruder and help prevent movement during X-Axis shifts.

Note:
This was designed so that only the magnetic ball bearings are the only thing touching the filament. This reduces the friction and helps create a smoother feed.

3mm magnetic ball are actually buckyballs, you can find them online.

Another good thing is to build a 608 ball bearing spool feeder, this will help reduce the friction and aid in a smoother filament feed.

Design by LOS

This is a key organizer.
It's simple to print and assembly.
I printed with 0.2mm layer height, PLA or ABS, whatever.

You will need:
(2) 5mm allen screw with countersunk head
(2) 5mm nyloc nut.

Use the spacer in between the parts and the keys, it will make the keys move smoothly.

I uploaded a version 2 of the nut part so you can decide which one do you prefer to put your key ring.

Hope you like and any other opinions is welcome.

description.text: This is my modification of Ladyada's excellent open source MintyBoost kit that is documented at http://www.ladyada.net/make/mintyboost. My modification consists of a custom PCB design based on the original schematic that it slightly larger than the MintyBoost's PCB but is single sided with no links and has room for two battery connections. It is still small enough to fit in a large Altoids tin along with 4x AA batteries. You have the option of running the MintyBoost XL at 2.4v - 3.0v by putting the two pairs of 2x AA batteries in parallel or running it at 4.8v - 6.0v by putting the two pairs of 2x AA in series. The LT1302 runs at a maximum input voltage of 8.0v so the higher voltage produced by the batteries in series isn't an issue. Running in parallel might cause issues if the battery packs are not evenly charged as it may result in the higher charged one draining into the lower one. You have the option to decide when building as there is room to connect them in parallel on the PCB. The resistors that I chose for the D+ and D- pins of the USB connector were 100k as I wanted it to work with my iPhone 3G. Some devices are fussier than others, most notably Apple's newer products, you may need to adjust the design to get it to work. See Ladyada's documentation and forums for more information about this. To etch the PCB I used the toner transfer method which is extensively described at http://www.fullnet.com/~tomg/gooteepc.htm. Basically it involves printing the track design onto photo paper with a laser printer and then ironing it onto the copper clad board. After it has transferred to the board it is soaked in water to remove the paper which leaves an etch resistant layer of toner on the copper board. It is then etched in a corrosive solution such as ferric chloride to remove the remaining copper. Be sure to wear safety glasses, protective gloves and suitable clothing when dealing with etching solutions and keep it away from anything metallic. The toner transfer method isn't perfect as the quality can vary quite a lot and requires a bit of tweaking. The real beauty of this method is that you can always scrub off the toner before you etch if you're not happy with the quality and try again. Altoid tins are notoriously hard to get hold of in the UK but luckily Marks & Spencer sell "Curiously Strong Mints" which are identical to Altoid mints and come in the same sized tin.

• Etch the board design onto copper clad board using your desired method.
  • Drill the holes in the etched board.
  • solder al of the components in place.
  • Cut a hole in the tin for the USB connector (Dremel or snippers are handy).
  • Insulate the metal by the circuit board and glue the board into place.
  • Insert 4x AA batteries.
  • Charge you gadgets on the go!
    • You will more than likely be stopped by airport security if you take try and take a device like this on board despite it being harmless.

title: Flyingbear P902 Z axis brackets and motor mounts

description.text:
Work in progress!

Z axis bracketry for the flying bear, I will do a few versions and update as I design and test them.

2/28/17- Bottom Z axis bracket for pancake stepper and custom bearing housing:

This is untested, but I dont think the flying bear Z stepper motor needs much of any torque. So I got a pancake stepper for my titan and decided to order another and try it on the Z axis. It is 15mm shorter which will give you 15mm more Z height (dont forget to enable in firmware!), and has 18.5 oz in of torque, compared to the stock bear 30 oz in. part number : 17HS08-1004S

http://www.omc-stepperonline.com/nema-17-bipolar-step-motor-35v-1a-13ncm184ozin-17hs081004s-p-101.html

The motor shaft will have to be shortened, you can cut it with a dremel. You will also need to get an extra stepper motor harness or cut and splice into the existing one, as its only a few inches long and un-terminated.

The bracket design also does away with the stock style bottom bracket, so the motor sits directly on the extrusion, which will give you another 3mm of Z height.

2 versions-
FB_Z_bottom_brkt_for_pancake_and_bearing_hsng_FINAL is to be used with a custom made bearing flange block that I machined to hold the Z lead screw with an 8mm ID ball bearing. 99% probably wont use this. Ill upload a picture later.
FB_Z_bottom_brkt_for_pancake_FINAL is for the vast majority of users. The motor slides in the bottom, and is attached with the 4 screws. The bracket then bolts in like the stock pieces.

description.text:
WARNING after a few months of daily use I'm starting to see some breakages, so be careful what you use these for. Particularly with petg, it seems to become crystalline and brittle after a while, so it's likely that it will break sooner or later. Don't use them for something where if it breaks it's going to matter!

There have been two types of breakages so far, the first is at the hinge of the carabiner, and the second is the loop for the middle of the strap. I've replaced the loop with a stronger version which will hopefully last longer, and added a new version of the carabiner with a more flexible hinge section. I haven't tested the new hinge much yet, so I don't know how well it will last.

A simple clip to use with 1" webbing. I needed three to make a light weight replacement for part of a dog harness, two with terminals that the webbing wraps around and one in the middle with a simple loop for the webbing to pass through.

The flex in the hinge of the carabiner is about right when printed with PETG.

The orientation of most of the parts seems a bit random - I started with the clip and designed the other parts in place, so you'll need to rotate them for printing. The terminal prints without supports if you rotate it so that the bar that the webbing wraps around is on the bottom (leaving the cutout on the top). The clamp obviously lies flat so that the print-head can run in ovals, but one side of it has a bevel to make it easier to slide onto the terminal. You want the bevel to be on the top when printing.

Update: I had some problems with the webbing slipping in the terminals, so I've made it a tighter fit with more aggressive angles, and also added a simple 'clamp' which slides over the webbing end of the terminal. Feed the webbing through the clamp before threading it through the terminal, then slide the clamp over both the webbing and the terminal to hold everything in place.

title: PVC Mount - Thrustmaster T.16000M HOTAS FCS

description.text:
The folks at Thrustmaster were gracious enough to give the T.1600M FCS system a pair of M6 bolts on the bottom of their HOTAS joystick and throttle combination. This is a big step up from the HOTAS X which was decent but had no way to attach it to anything.

This thing is a simple pair of mounts for attaching the joystick and throttle to your own 1.5" schedule 40 PVC frame. The small model (orange) is for the joystick, the large model (green) is for the throttle. The secondary arms on the joystick could probably be a little bigger, but it is very stable once attached to the PVC so I'm not sure there is any benefit. I've not modified the OpenSCAD file from the design I printed and photographed.

You will need 2x M6-1.0 bolts per piece (4 total) which are available at Lowes. The joystick can take up to 30mm length, and the throttle can take up to 20mm length, but I used M6x16mm hex head non-hardened bolts (92 cents for a pack of 4).

The design can be adapted to other PVC diameters just by changing the OD measurements pvc_od_a and pvc_od_b to the proper taper.

Printer:

C-Bot

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.24mm layer height

Infill:

30% cubic (or 15% rectilinear)

Notes:

Adjust the WALL variable to be a multiple of your extrusion width, so that you end up with 2 full perimeters per edge (4 printed extrusions to make the center cylinder wall).

Layer height is not important, up to 0.4mm is fine. There are no overhangs so it can be printed right up. I used Protoparadigm Ruby Red PLA (1.75mm), 2 perimeters, 2 bottom solid layers, 4 top solid layers. Filament use was 97g.

30% 3D cubic infill from the Prusa version of Slic3r was used, although I am sure that my normal 15% rectilinear infill would have been fine now that I see it printed.

title: Davinci 1.0 E3D V6 Easy Direct Fit Direct Drive

description.text:
After using all the info that I have gained from here I thought that it is time to contribute something back. I know that the 1.0's are a little dated but IMO it still is a great printer, even more so with good mods. I did not like many of the E3D mods that I have seen, they either require holes to be drilled or additional hardware or replacement of the whole carriage. I wanted something easier that would just install and work. I optimized the parts as best as I could to reduce support requirements when printing. This configuration uses the stock screws that hold the hot end in and the stock E3D parts from the kit.
I went a little overboard with the wiring and modifications to the main board but that is not necessary and just satisfied my OCD.

I am working on a 360 degree layer cooler.

YOU WILL LOOSE 24mm of z travel but to me this is a good trade off for simplicity.

title: BLTouch for Original Prusa i3 MK2

description.text:
Remix of the Original Prusa i3 MK2 extruder body and cover.

The problem that orginally spurred this project http://shop.prusa3d.com/forum/prusa-i3-kit-building-calibrating-first-print-main-f6/-hump-in-bed--t2668.html

While waiting for my replacement bed from Prusa, I acquired a 2mm aluminum sheet and used heat tape to attach it to the heatbed, placed a new PEI sheet over this and a lot of the issues I had were minimized. There were a few spot and they would still show on larger prints, not bad enough to ruin the finish, but still noticeable. The other problem was my PINDA probe was very close to the prints, I'd say about ~1mm above, LiveZadjust at about ~.15. I've already broken the probe holder on a stray piece of PETG. Luckily I was able to attach it long enough to print a replacement body.

Anyway, looking to try a 1/8" piece of glass attached to the heatbed to see if that will fix the surface issues that I have. Ordered a BLTouch probe a few weeks ago and have been figuring out how to mount it, how to wire it, what needs to be changed in the firmware, etc. This is the first iteration of the mount. I have not had the opportunity to mount it yet, that will come after I figure out the wiring and firmware side of things.

Original Prusa i3 MK2

Rafts:

comments.author: voltrove

comments.text:
and success. So for any other poor ignorant soul lucky enough to run across this...
I got this working under Windows 10 using the zipped version of Arduino.cc IDE v 1.8.1.
After unzipping, start Arduino IDE, File, preferences. Enter path found here http://reprap.org/wiki/Rambo_firmware#Arduino_1.6.4.2B_Board_Manager_Plugin
into the 'Additional Boards Manager URL', click OK.
Click on Tools, Board, Board Manager. Install the Rambo from under RAMBo by UltiMachine.
I also had to copy the bootloader from https://github.com/arduino/Arduino-stk500v2-bootloader/tree/master/goodHexFiles to
%userprofile%\AppData\Local\Arduino15\packages\rambo\hardware\avr\1.0.0\bootloaders

description.text: GoPro clip for wearing your GoPro camera on your clothes. On a pocket or similar edge on your clothing.

I printed this as it is without any supports, on a MakerBot Replicator 2X. I used Bendlay ABS as it is slightly more flexible than other ABS plastics. I Used Standard "Low" setting and changed layer to 0.25mm, and filling to 15%.  
I guess it will work also in other platsics

comments.text: I made one of these today with PLA and it printed perfectly.  BUT - the three fingers that interlock with the camera housing were a little thick, so I had to remove the bolt from one of the black twisty things that come with many of the GoPro camera mounts and use that.  It seems that you've shown an alternate bolt with your photos, so you likely already knew that.  Next problem - it fits very tightly to the camera housing.  It is very difficult to get on and off, and I needed to use a screwdriver.  It's so tight, that it is also impossible to open the clip up to slip it onto clothing.  I think this is a great idea because of it's simplicity, but I hope to see some improvements so that it can be more easily used in the field and installed in seconds.  It would also be awesome if another version was developed that could be flipped around and clipped from the opposite direction, or clipped above the brim of a baseball cap.

title: Reverse Z Brace for Duplicator I3 Plus

description.text:
Used and loved the Z Brace by spool3d_canada, but found that once I started using an enclosure the Z Braces began to get in the way. Following the lead of FilamentCorner's z Brace and z Extensions (Z-Kit) http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2012743, I decided to make a hybrid design that moved the braces to the back of the printer so as to be out of the way.

All of this is based on AzzA's original work which can be found here http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1444979.

The major differences of my design are the modifications to the single screw holes on the feet for the Duplicator I3 Plus. I also extended the feet design to project out farther to the sides so that I could utilize the tower side mounts made by FilamentCorner. Finally I added a space to mount an SD card extension cable on the front right foot of the printer so that I didn't have to fumble loading the SD card on the side of the printer.

Parts other than 3d printed:

  • 3/8 threaded rod - (2) 18" pieces
  • (4) 3/8 nut
  • (2) 3/8 washer
  • (2) 3/8 nylon nut
  • longer screws where necessary to attach to the frame (M5 10-15 I believe)
  • SDHC SD Card Reader Extension Cable KZ-B19 FPC UNIVERSAL

No incorporation of self leveling feet or such as it's pretty stable as is, but I may add those later.

My only real issue right now is that the angle on the side brackets doesn't allow for having a nut on the threaded rod on each side of the bracket. Perhaps going to a thinner rod would allow it. That said, the angle makes this thing pretty rock solid as is, so waiting to see if that's necessary.

update 3/10/2017

Added dumbcomputers tower feet (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1401030), fit perfectly

update 6/2/2017

corrected hardware size from 5/8 to 3/8 (the size the parts are designed for). I only had 5/8 parts on hand so I drilled holes to enlarge them and make them fit. If you buy 3/8 hardware everything should work for you with no drilling.

If you don't want the SD card foot, simple reverse the front left foot (mirror image) to get two "normal" front feet.

print_settings.Notes:: Print the adjusters and hinge parts with greater infill for strength.

description.text:
Version 6 is here!

What's new?
For starters, this one is smaller. Designed to fit a 16-17 inch neck, the old one, up to 22" The adjusters can be tweaked to enlarge the diameter, and I will be providing some larger hinges and front latches as well. For now, if you need a larger one, print the V2.0 collar. The collar is actually supposed to be pretty snug on your neck.

You will notice there are a lot more individual parts. This should help during the finishing stage, making it easier to sand. I will probably post some "Quick Prints" where some parts are combined, I'm not sure it really will save any time though.

The profiles for the Quadrants are closer to the screen used version.
Wire routing is much cleaner.
Redesigned hinge and adjuster pockets.
Upper quads have accommodations for real allen head screws.

The Battery compartment has been totally redesigned, and no longer requires a screw for battery removal.
There are 2 versions of the battery compartment posted. If you have time, and your prints are pretty good, I recommend you print V2 of the battery compartment. It's a lot more assembly, but way cooler! It does require a brass contact made from 0.16in X 0.25in brass stock. I got mine at a local hardware store for $1.50. I have printed 2 copies of the new battery compartment so far. You will probably need to do some sanding and trimming depending on how accurate your printer is. Most of my trimming was just sanding the parts.

I finally was able to model the cables, and get them to print. The wire models include the supports, so you will need to cut them off and clean the part up a little. The new cables are much closer in size and configuration to the screen used versions.

I might be a little obsessed with Zombie control collars. If you haven't seen the movie Fido it really is worth a watch!

If you make one of these feel free to add your input on printability and design.
I may tweak a few parts here and there, other than that this prop is ready to print assemble and wear!

Added battery screw for reference. It is hard to print, you can order the real deal from McMaster Carr.
The Battery compartment has been designed to accommodate a 123A Lithium battery. It lasts many hours, and is readily available. Version one of the Battery door and Battery compartment have holes in them so you can use a needle or a pin as a hinge pin.

I used IDE ribbon cable wires for the LEDs. I have included a wiring diagram for the LEDs, The resistors can go on either side of the LED, and there are many places to put them in the model. The parts include conduits for the wire. to power the LED on the side that does not have a battery compartment, pass a wire through the conduit just under the hinge.

K&J Magnetics
12.6mmx5mm Disks from N35 ZD3 Amazingly strong given their size. (4 Required)

Digikey supplied the Resistors and battery components
CF14JT10K0CT-ND 8.3 Ohm 1/4W Resistor (2 Required)
36-5223-ND CONTACT BATT W/TABS POSITVE A/AA (1 Required)
36-5201-ND CONTACT BATT W/TAB NEG SPRG A/AA (1 Required)

Part Number 91290A073 Alloy Screw (16 Required) Trim off the threads or drill parts.

Conduit
From an LED snake light I found on Amazon http://amzn.com/B003SSAEZ2 (Not required if you print the cable parts.)

Red "Lights"

https://www.amazon.com/Acrylic-Round-Translucent-Diameter-Length/dp/B00EVBTQ18/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1476491970&sr=8-1&keywords=acrylic++rod+red

Hardware Store
0.16in X 0.25in brass stock (0.42mm X 6.4mm) Brass stock for V2 Battery compartment contact

The chain plate had been included for reference. I did not print mine on the printer. Instead I took a pice of flat bar steel and glued (Welded actually) a half a link of chain to it. The sides of the collar have places to put magnets in to hold the chain anchor on. This way if anyone pulls too hard on the chain it pops off, protecting you and the prop! I got plastic chain at Lowes, and painted it silver.

Please note, this is NOT a screen accurate model, some liberties were taken, and parts were modified to simplify construction, and printing.

The parts in this model an be printed with minimal/no supports. The rear quadrants have a perforated web at the bottom to aid in bed adhesion, They will need to be cut off.

Print the adjusters and hinge parts with greater infill for strength.

I use Nitro Stan or Bondo Glazing putty after sanding with 120 grit, then finish sand with 220 and 400. Sanding blocks are included to sand the inside of the badge and the quadrants. 3m makes "3M SandBlaster Ultra Flexible Sanding Sheets" super awesome sandpaper, glue it to the sanding block for a perfect fit!

I print in ABS so the components are usually glued to each other with ABS doped acetone. Magnets can be epoxied into place

AG-3 ist eine Anti-Goa'uld-Satellitenwaffe, die Daniel Jackson in einer von Shifu erzeugten Vision konstruiert. In der Realitaet wurde dieses Waffensystem nie gebaut. Ursprung Um Daniel zu zeigen, dass das Wissen der Goa'uld zu maechtig fuer einen Menschen ist, und dadurch einem Goa'uld immer aehnlicher werden laesst, teilt Shifu dieses Wissen in einer Vision mit Daniel. Dieser faengt in der Vision kurze Zeit spaeter an, dieses Wissen zu nutzen, um eine Waffe zu konstruieren, die die Erde vor Goa'uld-Angriffen schaetzen soll. Spaeter nutzt er sie aber, um immer mehr Macht zu erhalten und zerstoert dabei sogar Moskau. Das AG-System Das AG-System besteht aus 288 Satelliten, die mit 24 Raketen, von denen jede 12 AG-3s traegt, in den Erdorbit befoerdert wurden. Jeder dieser Satelliten wird durch schweres FlÃ¼ssignaquadah mit Energie versorgt. Sie besitzen Langstreckensensoren, die Goa'uld-Raumschiffe ueber tausende von Lichtjahren orten koennen. Die Waffensysteme sind zudem in der Lage, die Goa'uld-Schutzschilde zu durchdringen und so Goa'uld-Raumschiffe zu zerstoeren. Die AG-3s koennen einzeln feuern oder ihre Energiestrahlen zu einem staerkeren buendeln. Die Bauzeit wurde auf zwei Jahre mit Kosten von 80 Milliarden Dollar veranschlagt, Daniel verlangte aber eine Fertigstellung nach einem Jahr, was die Kosten verdoppelte. Einsaetze Auf Anordnung des Praesidenten wurde ein russischer Satellit zerstoert, um den Russen die Feuerkraft zu demonstrieren.
Als die Russen sich nicht einschuechtern lassen und der amerikanische Praesident ueber eine Teilung der Kontrolle ueber das System nachdenkt, uebernimmt Daniel die Kontrolle und zerstoert Moskau, um die ueberlegenheit zu beweisen. [www.stargate-wiki.de] LED montage moeglich

title: Adventure Time Card Wars Deck Box

description.text:
Card Wars can be tricky to store due to the larger landscape tiles. This design uses the landscape tiles as a lid and holds everything together with a thick rubber band. It holds two decks + landscape tiles and has a storage space under each deck for storing damage tokens or dice (eight 16mm dice on each side). The deck box is also stackable and you can secure multiple boxes with a single rubber band.

Note: this is designed for un-sleeved cards. If you use sleeves you'll need to scale it up by some amount. 5% maybe... I dunno. Let me know if you try.

I designed this in onshape: https://cad.onshape.com/documents/e845a62bc91cf0a55e13c88f/w/cc063f5de2d2135bf24ba29f/e/e7e8fccfd0cfa07564c2a289

Totally new here and to 3D printing. Just got a CR10s. What would be the best filament to use thats fairly easy to print?
Thanks
comments.author: cyborblades

comments.text: Don't use the glass that comes with the printer. Instead go to Lowe's or Home Depot and buy a set of 6 glass mirrors for $10. Then order a 12"x12" (this won't fit perfectly, the CR10's build plate is actually 12.25 inches on a side, I believe) sheet of PEI from amazon and clamp it down to your mirrors when you print. As long as you keep your bed properly leveled you'll never have any issues with bed adhesion. Also when it's done you can unclamp the PEI and just barely twist it to have everything practically fly off the sheet.
comments.author: cyborblades

comments.text:
Yes I did get those mirror tiles from Home Depot for both my Cr10s printers. I bought the special surface for the plate but once I printed the dial indicator holder for these I never turned back. I only use magigoo on the glass. Tramming with the dial indicator is the bomb. No other thing needed and everything so far sticks great. I have not tried anything but PLA but I have ABS, CF, Wood, metals but never tried them yet. Having too much trouble keeping the printers running. Looks like I have bad mainboards in both. Gearbest has agree to send me one but are saying they are going to their tech team for the trouble with my second CR10s.
I was reading posts about the hotend which would you recommend?

comments.author: Chrizlle

comments.text: Works great, been using it for about a month now, at first i had issues getting the tube in without mangling the tube... i found an easy way to push in the PTFE tube was to use the same small Allen key used to re mold the tube after cutting it, take the same key and insert into the PTFE  tube, line up the hole and you can grab the key from the other side of the hole while pushing the PTFE tube into the hole with the key's 90 degree arm, that usually gets the tube right into where it needs to be but to be sure sometimes i remove the key, cut the tube leaving at least 1 cm or so of extra tube, reinsert key and then i can grab the tube at the extra 1 cm portion with pliers and really crank it into body without having to worry about damaging the part of the tube that matters, once its in place, remove allen key, cut off extra portion and cut the V shape. Hope it helps someone and thanks for the design!!

comments.text: Thank you for designing this. I've been using it successfully for some time now, but I wanted to share something I recently started experiencing. I originally printed two of these. One carbon fiber PLA and one ABS. I used the carbon fiber PLA version because it felt more rigid. I started to have under extrusion problems this weekend. Pilloying, missing layers, etc...  I looked for all the normal things, but what I failed to notice until today was the printed part had started bowing. The vertical portion containing the feed hole had angled slightly. I guess the heat from the stepper motor and the spring pushing onto it eventually caused a failure.  I swapped it out with the ABS printed copy and so far so good. Hopefully ABS will be heat tolerant enough to withstand bowing.

title: Labelled caps for OSL calibration loads

description.text:
Those who use Antenna Analysers, and similar devices, will like to periodically calibrate them with OSL (Open, Short & Load) terminators. These are easy to make out of OTS BNC or SMA connectors, but they look so much nicer when they have a labelled cap on them. This thing is 3 caps - 0 ohm, 50 ohm and Open Circuit for such terminators.

Construction is straightforward.
Cut off all center pins.
0 ohm simply has a wire soldered from center pin to body.
Open Circuit simply has center pin cut off.
50 ohm is tricky. I have seen 2 x 100 ohm SMD 1206 resistors soldered direct from center pin to body. I had great difficulty doing this, and they kept breaking. I just soldered 2 back-to-back, put flying leads on them, and they fit inside the body.

description.text:
This is part of a kinetic sculpture I designed called Digital Rain (the rest is my gyroid construction set, listed as a "remixed from"). It's best experienced in person, but since it's in my basement for now, a video will have to do: https://youtu.be/fdcw1tt5CR4

Being modular, you can make this as tall as you want (mine is 10 units high, or about four feet). I power it with a 12V gear motor I picked up off eBay that I run at 6V to get about 15 RPM. It only takes a few watts of power. It's pumping about 1,500 5mm steel bearing balls.

This pump and track system requires no glue or fasteners for assembly, it all just fits/snaps together. The track pieces have two little ears to help keep them from curling off the bed; those need to be cut off before assembling. I mounted the motor to the underside of the lid of a wooden box and then used double-sided tape to stick the bottom of the pump to the top of the lid. The drain and collector pieces are tied together through some mosquito netting with a small hole cut in the middle. This is a reliable way to collect balls from a wide area without making a deafening sound.

The main body of the double helix pump was designed to be an attractive and efficient means of lifting a lot of small steel balls. I chose this design because it does not need accurate tolerances: the rotor is significantly smaller than the stator, but the balls act like a bearing and keep everything centered. The track is designed so its own weight keeps the segments locked together, and it forces the balls to flow in single-file which keeps them from getting stuck. The most design iterations were actually around subtleties of the drain and the top of the pump to ensure reliable operation without the balls getting stuck or escaping. I've run this for more than an hour at a time and so far it's holding up well.

description.text: This is a small hinge suitable for use on jewellery boxes or similar small-scale products.  It was designed and printed in less than 40 min as a demonstration of 3-D printing in a design lesson at the school I work at.

I recommend you use, solid settings. On my printer. The support structure came away easily, and by flexing the hinge snapping the remaining internal supports it works well.
The hinge itself was designed using pro desktop 3-D software that is often used in schools in the UK.

description.text:
These are various adapters to connect a vacuum hose to various different tools in my workshop. The vacuum is provided by a relative cheap compact canister vacuum (https://smile.amazon.com/gp/product/B007JN6MQC) with a 10' hose (https://smile.amazon.com/gp/product/B00LPOUW2Q) attached using a 3d printer bracket. The hose is then adapted for various pieces of equipment. The hose connector mate using magnets making it super simple to plug and unplug the vacuum depending on what I'm doing.

Parts:

Vacuum connector - connects the 10' hose to the canister vacuum.
Hose connector - connects the 10' hose to a magnetic hose connector.
Sand connector - connects the hose connector the 2.5" port on my belt sander.
Loc-Line connector - connects the hose to loc-line (anchored)
Generic connector - template to mate with the hose connector.

title: U-Wing Bin for Harbor Freight Organizer (X-Wing TMG)

description.text:
Large, half-height bin for a pair of U-Wings.

This is part of my Harbor Freight X-Wing collection.

I'd like to thank Matt a.k.a. ryanvito for his help in pulling this design together.

Basically I sketch the outline on paper, measure out a set of points to make a polygon around the outside of the ship, and then code that up in OpenSCAD as a first step in the blank. Then I measure the depth I believe the bin will need to be to nest the ship just right, and typically create a cutout in the bottom to save some plastic.

The "bintools" code is then responsible for creating a test outline that is cheaper/faster to print to see if things are right, and also to place the outline in a bin (in this case two of them).

Ryanvito did the test prints for this one, which is always a help. Thanks!

description.text:
This was based on a small statue that I modified a little to make it easier to print.

The stl's are each made of several manifolds with positive volumes. They slice fine for me with Repetier Host for Mac.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1mm

Notes:

Import version Buddhist_Statue_050_no_head_support . Units are in mm.
Turn on support material.

Set perimeters to 4 and base layers to 15.

If the back of the head slides off the support column while printing, then use Buddhist_Statue_50_modified_robes, turn support material on, and print.

Pick the support material off and slide the hands in the slot.

Optional: Round Out the Back

Remember how I said 4 perimeters and 15 base layers? It seemed excessive right? Well, now that means if you want to round out the back of the figure, you can do that without putting any holes in the surface. You can use a dremel with a carving bit, or a grinding bit, or a sanding bit, or you can use a hand file, or you can use a carving knife, or you can just scrub with rough sandpaper.

title: Anet a8 Butter slider X carriage for e3dv6 with built in 8mm bearings for Tech2c Mount and endstop
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
After trying to install PLA printed LM8UU bearings on the prusa i3 rework by emotion techs
X carriage I noticed the X carriage wasn't fitting correctly.. my printers dimensions were around .5mm off from that design.. So if you've ordered a anet recently(AFTER FEB2017) and have the same issue this works great Slides like butter and no need for zipties anymore.. Check your space between the rails with a caliper and mine was around 54mm im sure within a .1 tolerance is fine, meaning 54.1mm is fine or 53.9mm should work on your Anet.
Print it on its side cause the bearing holes will warp if you print it flat..
If u don't want to print the whole thing to make sure it fits u can print around 10% of the design then stop it then remove rails and test it check my photos for reference.
Fyi if U need to file the bearing holes a bit to get it to slide like butter just don't file a lot cause its almost a perfect fit.
Other changes are the screws I made to work with M3 screws and it screws in from the front now with a m3 nut in the back. Don't forget to oil ur rails and print with the endstop touching builplate and for m3 nut use the heat method to press it in.

NEW UPDATE heres my hotend mount and blower fan version
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2162732
https://youtu.be/fCvlAIAdF4g

Enjoy

a8

OMG... this is the BEST part I've ever printed. It fits PERFECTLY on my A8 (purchased Fall 2017). There's zero play or wobble. Slides just like... mmmm BUTTER. No oil needed at this point but after I have a few hours on it, I'll probably put a dab or two on just for longevity. I love the endstop addition too. The Tech2c one was just a touch too short and the endstop would almost bend because it was only engaging by hitting the very corner.
Amazing job 3DTSUJ, I will tip on payday because quality parts like this deserve to be rewarded. I suggest anyone who's considering a new x-carriage stop the search now and just print this one. I printed it on .2 but 100% infill because I wanted it absolutely sturdy. It's a bit overkill but to be honest the way it came out I do not regret it at all. Thanks again!

description.text:
This useless artifact appeared in my hand in a dream, and I've tried to recreate it.

It is a die that defeats its own purpose. Every side is the same. Ideally, every side should be indistinguishable from every other side, but the paint smudged a little as you can see in the picture.

Each face is subdivided into the numbers 1 through 6. The total number of dots per side is 21, but that's just incidental. A normal die is supposed to collapse from an undetermined state to a determined state. When you shake it in your cupped hands it is undetermined. When it lands on the table, it rolls, say, a 5, and then the state is determined. But this die never arrives at a determined state. It is like Schrodinger's cat-box scenario where you NEVER get to open the box to see if the cat is alive or dead.

The dream may have been taunting my idea of "free will" by implying that we live in a strict deterministic universe. However, it's more likely driving at one of my fears as a child: the fear that there could be intrinsic properties of the universe which we may NEVER know. Contemplating Russell's Paradox can lead to some interesting mathematical conclusions about things we can never prove.

Preparation: Orientation and Scaling

If you print 50A (flat), then the top and bottom would be distinguishable from the sides, so the die will not work. You could roll it for a 1/3 chance of getting a side you could distinguish from the others. Therefore, it's best to print with the "poles" facing up and down. Use 50B and choose support material or use 50C, which produces a customized "scaffold" that pulls right off. You can use a file or sandpaper to remove the little nubs from the stand and hide the evidence of which corner it was. I used a scaling factor of 5 and a layer height of 0.1mm to make the scaffold work.

If I design a better scaffold I'll upload more files.

I used regular acrylic paint with a small paintbrush.

This is a light wand that uses a 60 LED strip and a small embedded microcontroller to control the LEDs. I have included the Arduino source code with the thing files. A demo of the wand operating can be found here: http://youtu.be/sn-klYeQRcA You can programmatically make any light sequence you want by altering the source code. This uses 3 AA batteries to power the LED strip and the microcontroller. The battery compartment is printed inside the handle of the wand. The battery door is held in place by a single M3x20 screw. information on how to install Arduino for the Trinket microcontroller can be found here: http://learn.adafruit.com/introducing-trinket/setting-up-with-arduino-ide Information on how the LED strip works can be found here: http://learn.adafruit.com/adafruit-neopixel-uberguide/power Trinket Microcontroller can be purchased here: http://www.adafruit.com/products/1501 LED strip can be purchased here: http://www.adafruit.com/products/1138

I printed all parts in White ABS except for the LED cover, which is printed in T-Glase. you obviously want this to be as transparent as possible.   
The batteries are wired with a heavy gauge single conductor wire. Place the wire through the small hole at the bottom of the battery contact. Place a small drop of super glue on the wire above the battery contact to keep the wire in place, making sure you don't get any glue on the contact itself.   
Wire the negative terminal to GND on the trinket and the positive terminal to BAT. connect the 5v and gnd wires to the the same BAT and GND pins you just wired the batteries to. Connect the signal wire from the LED strip to output zero on the Trinket, although you could wire it to another output if you don't mind altering the source code. Make sure you run the wires through the hollow compartment in the handle. You can solder the wires directly to the bottom of the Trinket PCB to keep it nice and neat.   
Remove the LED strip from the silicone casing and wrap the LED strip around the shaft of the wand, making sure that the strip is touching itself as you wrap it around. I used a few drops of hot glue to secure the strip to the shaft. This will allow you to take it off again if you want to reuse it.  
Once you have verified everything is working, secure the cover to the handle with a little super glue.

title: Screwless hinge and latch for Ultimaker 3 door

description.text:
A remix of thing:1364236 , Simple Customizable Hinge by tommckearney and thing:10541 , Pin Connectors V2 by tbuser for my Ultimaker 3 Extended.

Hinges: I made them smaller and deleted the holes so I could use double sided tape. I've played around with stretching, so they might need a little bit of smoothing to go flawlessly.

Latch: the part of the latch that holds the door is 11m high. For my 4mm door, that left me with about 2mm free, which I filled with 4 pieces of foamy tape so it's squishy and doesn't scratch the plexiglass.

I used a 40 x 28 cm size, 4mm thick, plexiglass

UPDATE: I used a cheaper double sided tape, and with time, I'm guessing from the heat generated by the printer, it started to slide, thus the door ending up touching the rotary wheel of the printer. So use some super glue if you want, or high quality double sided tape.

This stand helps you to use a 35x7.5mm DIN rail on your desktop for prototyping, testing, etc.
It's a remix of DIN Rail Stand by dev67. There are three minor modifications:

  • Use of an intermediate tolerance of the din rail cutout,
  • an additional hole to secure the rail with a screw, and
  • slightly slimmer stands.

With the intermediate tolerance in the cutout, my printed version fits snugly after pushing the DIN rail in. To further secure the rail, I included a tap hole of 3.3mm to cut an M4 screw thread into it (if you have a die at hand). There is enough space to use an 9mm wide washer when securing the rail with the M4 screw.
Please note that this thing is made for the regular DIN rails (35x7.5mm), not the deep ones (35x15mm).
Keeps phone upright and off desk.

title: Stanley FATMAX Deep Pro Organizer Base Clip

description.text:
UPDATE I posted my own remix v2 with a hinge instead of sliding on. It's a little bit more complicated to print and assemble but works more like the original mechanism.

A base clip for Stanley FATMAX Deep Pro Organizers. It can be used to attach the lowest organizer to a rolling board. Slide it onto the organizer to secure it. There is a regular and a low version:

  • Use the low version if your board is so small that the four feet of the organizer don't sit on top.
  • Use the regular version if the organizer sits on its feet when placed on your board.

The slotted holes allow sliding the clip on and off the. With the torque of the screws you can adjust how strongly they grip the organizer.

Most likely it also fits the Stanley FATMAX Shallow Pro Organizer but I didn't test that one.

is equipped magnetic lock (magnet diameter 8mm, 5mm long) and it works like transport box as well.
I know, that the surface is not excellent, but not because of design, but printing process. So don't be afraid to print it.

Stones

are from Europe, Czech Republic: http://bushcraft.cz/vybaveni/noze-a-nastroje/keramicke-brousky-belsky-br/

č. 104 (A, B): BELSKY TRIANGEL, délka (lenght) 200 mm, strana(side) 12 mm, vrcholy (edges) trianglu: 1 x ostrý (sharp), 1 x kulatý průměr (round dia.) 1 mm, 1 x kulatý průměr (round dia.) 2 mm. Cena 110,- Kč (cca.4€).

I have also made this sharpener: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1274297
It give the precise shape, but than I aplly this one, to have sharper blade.

The diamond pencil is good to use for really dull knifes, if you haven't other possibility for first modification of shape (for example like this http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1274297 ). Than I recommend to apply hard stones and than the finishing stones.

I chose the angle 20°, 30°, 40° but you can modify the design in Tincercad: https://www.tinkercad.com/things/2hasCCVXy6x

The diamond sharpener pencil is from Ebay.

There are instruction, how to use it: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=s2DDpB8Pjho

I have made this holder for all dial indicator, without a holder on the back.

The hole is 8mm and match all dial indicator.

I tried first to place the dial on the extruder head, so I could move it around with the head.
It turns out that the weight from the dial, alone did change the readings and result.
So I ended up with a remix of another mount, that matches my indicator.

I hope that this is useful for others here.

Please add comments if I could change something in the design.
It took me 5 attempts to get this version at a useful stage.

I have added 2 versions one with support and one without support. Because repetier host did not want to create proper support for this.
I do also recommend to print this at a 45 degree angle to the heatbed, because the printer head keeps getting stuck for me, and thereby loosing steps in the y direction.

This print requires:
2 x M3 nuts
1 x M3 bolt 8mm long (12mm with head)
1 x M3 bolt 45mm long (48mm with head)

Best regards
Søren

title: Portable Star Trek 3D Chess with Low Profile Pieces

description.text: This is a 3D chessboard inspired by Star Trek, including a matching set of low profile chess pieces. It can be disassembled and transported easily. See instructions for required materials and assembly notes. For "standard" rules of play, and the most easy-to-follow explanation of the game I have found, I refer you to Charles Roth's site at http://www.thedance.net/~roth/TECHBLOG/chess.html. Additionally, there is a slightly different set of "tournament" rules maintained by Jens Meder at http://home.arcor.de/jens.meder/3dschach/chess3d.htm. Thanks for pointing out the "tournament" rules goes to Doug Keenan, http://www.thingiverse.com/dougkeenan. Doug also has created an excellent 3D (and 2D) chess program called Parmen, available along with many other related resources at http://www.parmen.com/. Note that this design does not allow attack board inversions... so you can just play without inversions. Enjoy!

Requires a length of 1/4" threaded rod, some fender washers for a base weight, a cap nut that fits into the top board, and a wing nut to hold it all together.  
Some parts have additional material that needs to be removed/cleaned up before assembly.  This includes small rafts at the corners of the base and boards, and on the attack board pins, which help them to stay on your build plate without warping or popping off.  The holes where the threaded rod goes through the base and main boards must also be drilled or cut out.  
The attack board pins (ab stem pin.stl) are glued into the attack board stems (ab stem.stl) to form the finished stems.  You may need to clean up the holes in the attack boards and main boards, and sand the stem pins a little, to get everything to fit together properly.  
The black squares are printed separately and then glued into the various boards as an inlay.  There are separate files for the corner black squares as well as the black squares on the attack boards.  
You will want to glue some felt on the bottom of the chess pieces, to keep them from sliding off the boards.  I also glued felt to the bottom of the base.

print_settings.Notes:: I updated all 3 files for better fitting these things togehter.

description.text: This thing is modified from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1925678 . Great idea to save space for the collected fleet of 3DBenchy's. I modified it to make it stackable. So you can save much more space.

Printer:

Prusa I3 MK2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.20

Infill:

25%

Notes:

You need at least one of all the 3 parts. The middle part (part 2) can be printed as often you want. These part ist stackable. Part 4 is optional.

Update(s):

  • I updated all 3 files for better fitting these things togehter.
  • add a rubber base (file #4). Print it with some flexible material.

Assembly instructions

After printing the parts you need an aluminium tube (8mm diameter) for stacking the parts together. I also use leftofer LM8UU-bearing for better gliding inside part 2, but it will works without it too. Just press the bearing in the lower part of part 2, it's strong, but it will fit.

The length of the aluminium-tube depends on the # of stackable middle parts :

total length = n+1 x 70mm where n is the # of stacks

Press the tube inside part 1, slide part(s) 2 over the tube and attach, with some force, part 3.

Tip for better standing

If you pause the print at layerheight 4.40mm you can insert an big and heavy washer inside part 1. But be careful, the washer must fit perfect, the nozzle must never touch the washer, otherwise you will damage your hotend !!!

Resume the print after placing the washer and continue.

Link for used washer : http://www.ebay.de/itm/191669696962
(use the 65x3mm washer)
Scanned with the MakerBot Digitizer Desktop 3D Scanner. It's the Adipose alien from Dr. Who. Stress reliever toy I got for Christmas!

title: Raspberry Pi Camera to Microscope Adapter

description.text:
These two pieces fit together in order to adapt a Raspberry Pi Camera to a Celestron microscope.  
The first piece (rectangular one) fits the Raspberry Pi camera, while the second piece (cylindric tube) fits the microscope. The two pieces snap together.  
The OpenSCAD design has also an alternative cylinder for adapting to the eye piece of a telescope (work in progress).

Designed it with OpenSCAD, by taking caliper measurements of the Raspberry Pi camera board, and the Ocular piece of a Celestron microscope. The prototype was printed with a Printrbot Simple (http://www.kitware.com/blog/home/post/579) using PLA filament. Repository at
https://github.com/luisibanez/ShapesFor3DPrinting

description.text: This is a small counter to keep track of your characters life (Or any other number you would like). It's easy to make for bigger or smaller numbers just by printing extra number-cogs. It's hold together by a small rubber band that is attached to the end-caps inside of the counter (You should be able to pull it through the arc and around the part to fasten it). When changing it, you just pull it apart a little, turn the cogs and then the rubber band locks it in place again.

title: Kitchenaid stand mixer to Milescraft 90 degree drill adapter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Prototype for coupling the Kitchenaid stand mixer attachment hub to a Milescraft 1390 90-degree drill adapter. This piece failed fairly quickly, with the set screws getting forced back over their threads and no longer gripping the Milescraft shaft. But I think if you just screw the set screws directly into the tap holes rather than tapping the holes first the fit will be tighter and more long-lived. The newer model is very similar and has lasted longer so far with this approach. http://www.shapeways.com/model/510417/ http://absurdlycertain.blogspot.com/2012/04/kitchenaid-drill-adapter.html http://absurdlycertain.blogspot.com/2012/05/update-diy-hario-conical-burr-grinder.html

There are two holes at tap size #29 designed for 8-32 set screws (3/16" length is good).  McMaster 94355A182 is fine, for which you'll want hex key 7122A15.  For most 3D print materials, you're better off driving the set screws directly into the piece rather than trying to tap the piece first.  that will keep the fit tighter and hopefully the piece will fail less quickly.

title: Anet A8 Mainboard and Twin Mosfet Enclosure Remix

description.text:
I remixed this thing to fit my Anet A8 which has the "stiffi" style frame brace. I had to cut a section out on the side of the case and lid due to the lower support of the frame brace.

I also opened up the hole for the 80mm fan so there is no restricted air flow. I added a fan cover from the power supply cover.

As you can also see in the photo's I had to cut about 6mm off the end of the heat sink on the mosfet as it was preventing the cover from installing correctly. This shouldn't be an issue as the size of the heat sink is overkill for this printer and heat bed.

comments.author: ranita

comments.text: Printed on my Anet A8 that has a glass hotbed upgrade using hair spray, also make the X and Y belt tensions before this print. No rafts, no support used a 5mm brim, 35% infill, 0.2 layer height, print cooling off 240 nozzle / 100 bed. Didn't have any problems with bed adhesion using ABS plastic although would recommend 7mm as 5mm was on the limit. Print suffered from curling due to temperature drops/ drafts in the room especially at 5% to 35% layers printing the overhang. Using tweezers to push down the excessive curling helps a lot also use some cardboard to prevent drafts if needed and masking tape to prevent other drafts from the cooling fan blowing around your part.

print_settings.Notes:: I printed this in PETG with fairly little infill for a bit of flex. Feel free to experiment - it shouldn't make much difference though.

title: 20cm glass supports (stock Micromake D1 bed heater)

description.text:
I couldn't stand the stock Micromake glass clips as they were too tall, hence the part fan duct of the stock extruder would crash into them on bigger prints.

So I made some low profile glass clips/clamps to hold it in place without protruding above the glass surface. The glass is kept in place purely because it fits between the clips snug enough..and then gets properly fixed by the screws.

Printed in PETG with fairly little infil to keep them slightly flexible so they fit the shape of the glass better. This was made for a 20cm round glass.

Happy printing :)

Printer:

Micromake D1

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Any

Infill:

25

Notes:

(For some reason Thingiverse previews it in an odd orientation. Make sure to lay it flat on the bed)

I printed this in PETG with fairly little infill for a bit of flex. Feel free to experiment - it shouldn't make much difference though.
